I munched on my wrap, which only cost me $5.50 and was actually really good! Not too much caesar dressing, and just the right amount of grilled chicken. There's another place down the street that also does a chicken caesar wrap with cold chicken, doesn't nearly compare to this one in quality.

Their pastries looked fresh, but the lasagna did not. I would opt away from lasagna at this coffee shop/cafe, unless you want a long afternoon in the bathroom and a rough n' tumblin tummy.

So yea...Chicken Caesar Wrap with Lavash bread at Cafe Bianco is definitely a winner. I'm asking that they add some olives next time.
author: matt m.

description:
Decent sandwich shop in the Financial District. I love all the mismatched tables and chairs. Gives this place a nice Euro feel. 

I went with the 1/2 chicken salad sandwich on wheat bread with swiss cheese and a bag of chips and a freshly squeezed lemonade. The chicken salad was ok, but lacking flavor a bit. Salt mostly. But I love how it came with a pickle slice and pepperoncini. Nice touch. The lemonade was REALLY good. 

All that for $7. Not bad at all considering the location.
author: Jen D.

description:
Out late last night.  Now hungover and in a climate controlled office downtown.  Bad air.  Staring at a computer screen.  Feeling gross.  Need to get out.  Need nourishment.  

What does any of this have to do with Cafe Bianco, you ask?  

The answer is simple, Cafe Bianco has the best vegetarian Minestrone soup around and it helped sooth my wretched condition.    

now if I could only find a conference room or something so I can take a nap.
Why did I even come to work?
author: G L.

description:
OK, I completely reverse my position on this place. They've exonerated themselves. Luckily, I did return here despite my last review's oath and, incidentally, was served by the same people as last time. However, they were actually very, very nice this time. Extremely accommodating, and I was a little taken aback, to be honest. 

It seems like they're making leaps and bounds of substantial progress, and I'm forgiving them. I sincerely hope they keep it up.
author: Federico E.

description:
Maybe you are risk averse and want only the simple meat-cheese-lettuce and bread sandwich that you make for yourself at home.  Maybe you are an Earl of Sandwich classist, and don't like your subs tarnished with embellishments.  Or perhaps you work at 44 Montgomery and have 7 minutes to eat your lunch.  Any of these would be perfectly valid reasons to visit Caffe Bianco.

I, unfortunately, enjoy things such as vegetables, spreads, and, if I'm feeling particularly red-blooded, maybe even some sauces.

It was a bland and dreary lunch for me.
author: John F.

description: This place serves up a fairly large selection of sandwiches and hot dishes.  I've tried the turkey club sandwich, breakfast burrito and the pre-made Ciabatta sandwich.  Hands down - the best bet is the pre-made Ciabatta sandwich: turkey or salami.  Both options are winners!  As for the turkey club, it was mediocre at best...something I could make better at home.  The breakfast burrito was just plain terrible.  It's overpriced and bland.
author: Lisa R.

description:
This place gets 4 stars because it's quick, the food is decent, and the price is right.  The pre-made, house special salami sandwiches on chiabatta bread are great and huge, and you get one plus a drink for $6.00.  If you want more, have the meatloaf sandwich or the meatball sandwich, or the Skyscraper club.

I'm not a "lunch" guy.  What I want is decent food that I can grab in 10 minutes or less and drag back to my desk so I can stare at Yelp for a few minutes before going back to work.  This place fits the bill excellently.  You can't eat at Tadish's (or Aqua) every day.
author: Ben P.

description:
Caffe Bianco makes for a weird place. It has a European-style seating area, makes decent sandwiches, and have fairly quick service (a necessity when you're on your way to a meeting and your beemer is double-parked). So they definitely satisfy some essential criteria for lunch in yuppie-land. But then come the parts that weird me out.

First, across the little corridor is another cafe or branch of the cafe. Or maybe it's the Bianco annex. Whatever it is I can't figure it out. They seem to have a decent salad bar, although I am far too fond of meat and carbs to eat that shit for lunch. It creeps me out and they should get their shit together and either make it one place, with a coherent decor, or just really make it obvious, and paint one place black or some shit.

Secondly, there is a really angry man with a moustache manning the register. He doesn't seem to really have his shit together, and it takes a long time for him to ring people up, creating a long line. But I can only assume that he owns the place, because not only is he kind of short with customers, but he barks orders and complains to the sandwich staff, even though they seem to be working hard and (almost) never screw up my order, unless moustache man was the one who took it down. Mr. Moustache Man, if you are the owner, let your staff do the work, sit down with an espresso and the "gazzetto dello sport", and live of the profits. You're not helping!

Lastly, their lasagna sucks! I love lasagna, I eat it and make it all the time. But theirs is honestly weird. the beef is all pale, and there doesn't seem to be any bechamel sauce in it. it is like buying frozen lasagna at safeway and cooking it in the microwave, but it costs you $6 or so, instead of $0.35.

Despite all this, I come all the time. It's literally across the street from my work, so it is too convenient. But stick to the ready-made salami-cheese ciabatta, or the melts. Don't experiment with the pre-made "Italian" food. And don't be nice to the Moustache Man, cause he won't be nice to you.
author: Anders L.

description:
So my office building decided to schedule a fire drill and evacuate our floor...minutes before a presentation call with a client. Uhm, panic.

Luckily, Caffe Bianco has free wifi AND upstairs seating that no one seems to know about, so I was able to scramble over and hop on my call with a few seconds to spare.

Caffe Bianco, yay.

I also love their super simple breakfast burritos with egg whites, cheese, salsa and bacon.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
A trip back to the 1920s, or 1940s, or 50s, or 70s, this lunch push-a tray-and-point joint occupies both sides plus the upstairs of a cramped "arcade" in a dark old wedge-shaped office building.  Red wine poured generously into chipped little glasses is a perfect accompaniment to highly cooked soups and dutch crunch bread toasted with some orange fat spread.  Between being refrigerated cold and the vin-o-vac stopper, its' a remarkably fresh glass of vino for $3.50.

If you are on the run from somebody they will never look for you here.  Beware the incessant light piano jazz.
author: Gil S.

description: Liked the ambiance.  Breakfast sandwich took a long time to come out but tasted good.
author: K L.

description:
Besides the slight long wait,  the sandwiches are made to order. My favorite is their Salami-Balsamic Ciabatta and second, the Caesar wrap. All sandwiches can be toasted. Their pastas also looks healthy and delicious but it's a meal I would only order for dinner. 

A salad buffet is available in the room next door for your own salad creation to-go, 1lb =$5.25.  You can also dine upstairs if you want to be away from the lines and noise. This cafe gives off an old charming SF financial district feel. You'll notice the many customers eating and chatting in their black or navy business suits.  

For eating in, you can walk up the stairs for a more quiet atmosphere. It's the most convenient lunch spot for me since my building is directly across the street.
author: Oanh N.

description: I would love to give this place 5 stars -- great environment and pretty good food. Here's my rub -- they charge more for coffee when you bring your own mug (mine is 15oz). They always charge me for a 20oz coffee, not even a 16oz coffee, when I bring my own cup. Call me cheap, or an environmentalist, but I they lose my business when there are dozens of other coffee stops that incentivize bringing your own mug. Get with it guys. Everything else is all good...
author: Vroom V.

description: I am writing this review for essentially one item theme, their breakfast sandwiches.  They are the only thing I have had from there and they are really tasty.  I am keen on good quality eggs (in my household I am known as the egg-whisperer), and this place is legit.  I recommend their wrap (tasty and cheap) but any other sandwich with egg involved is tasty.
author: Brian G.

description:
Perfect for solid lunch fare at a reasonable price. 

Great salad sampler-- beet salad, green bean salad, potato salad... you name a veggie and I am sure they'll make a salad out of it. The meatloaf sandwich is yummy. My co-worker swears by the chicken Caesar salad.

For mornings go for the breakfast burrito. Comes with a nice bit of fruit salad.

A smidge on the dirty side. I saw a staff member kill a cockroach behind the bagel toaster once, but at least they killed it.
author: Brad C.

description:
This place gets two starts because the space is nice and the service was very friendly and prompt.  Lots of pretty women coming and going from this place in their business suits, heels and take-out salads so if you are into business-suity women, the scenery is great.  

The food is shite!
author: B G.

description: Update - service has been a bit faster since the very long wait i had.  Maybe they were having and off day.  Still not as fast as i'd like but gotta admit, great food and the staff if very friendly
author: Craig G.

description:
Caffe Bianco is a no frills lunch spot with a bit of an odd atmosphere.  Every time I go there are a bunch of the "senior crowd", folks above 60, having lunch.  Odd.  

Their wraps are decent, and I typically stick with those and an iced tea.  For the price, for an average but decent lunch, and an atomosphere condusive to seniors, it's a ho hum alternative for lunch.  It works when you're too lazy to think of anything else to eat.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Very relaxing traditional cafe. A great vegan wrap (lavash) and good (though simple and small) sandwiches. (The lasagna is sweet and disgusting.) The pick-3-salads lunch is also good. But great is the breakfast. The breakfast burrito is clearly the best in the FiDi and one of the City's best. But it's the simpler options that really shine: a toasted baguette with butter or a hard-boiled egg enjoyed with a perfect Americano or French Roast.

The setting is perfect. Right level of bustle. Solid and non-annoying staff. Free wifi. Stable, marble-topped cafe tables! Perfect place to meet after work (BART, buses) or enjoy a long read. World Cup was great here giving me hope that the new nighttime hours will work as well.
author: Mike R.

description: My mom and I got the bacon & egg breakfast burritos on the run one morning.  I am rather disappointed.  Maybe because we are from Texas but these things were beyond bland even with the salsa.  I will not be returning.
author: Kacie C.

description:
I just 'discovered' this place the other day.

It does not look like much from the outside but once in I found a great old school interior with a tremendously high ceiling - and a very well priced menu. It reminded me of the kind of place you might find in Paris or London. Faded grandeur, unreconstructed. I was also delighted to see that it opened into an (Edwardian?) indoor shopping arcade, which is very European. I have never seen another one here in SF.

I had the veggie lasagne and it was served by a sweet lady and came with a very fresh side salad. The guy behind the counter pulled me a really excellent, smokey espresso. I sat in the late afternoon, the place was almost empty, and had a relaxing meal, enjoying the pure, slightly shabby but homey old-worldliness of it. 

I will be back.
author: Alison S.

description:
Years ago, when I first came to SF on vacation, I stumbled into this cafe for a quick bite to eat. I remember ordering a burrito, and a side salad, and was quite satisfied. Pretty affordable after a week of tourist traps (Boudins, places of Fisherman's Wharf... I did 'em all).

And now I find myself working across the road from this same cafe which fed me well all those years ago. I come to the salad bar about once a week... no longer buying burritos from here though (better places across SOMA). 

Whilst some people rave about Mixt Greens, I'm quite happy to put together my little concoction of lettuce, spinach, corn, beets, carrots and tuna (with low fat honey mustard). Something simple... just what I need.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Spacious & cosy breakfast/lunch/coffee oasis.  

If you are tiring of starbucks,  this old school spot is a good escape from the office to sip some joe and chill.

...and they make a mean tuna on rye.
author: Dpb T.

description:
We call this place Hemingway's.  I had to do some crazy research to find out its real name, since every time I go to lunch these days I always call Brandi and ask if she wants to have a Hemingway beer with me. 

Hemingway?  I mean, I thought he died in Florida.  So weird that he chose to haunt this place.
author: Danielle G.

description: Stumbled in here while looking for the Galleria entrance (yes I was turned around).  Wonderful espresso.  Will be back.
author: Amelia C.

description:
The best fruit and breakfast bar in the mornings!!!  You can make your own yogurt parfait with granola and fresh fruits daily.  They have cottage cheese or greek non fat yogurt - the good stuff.  The lunch timesalad bar is pretty awesome too, a really good selection of toppings and always fresh.  They have really good coffee (if you want to stay away from big corporate chains - this is the spot to go).  This place is located just across the street from my work so the convenience makes it all the better.

The owner Bennie is friendly and welcoming.  The staff is friendly too considering the place can get pretty busy during the morning and lunch time rush - so just be patient it will be well worth it without hurting your wallet :)

The seating isn't dressed to impress, but I have never had a problem finding somewhere to sit with my lunch mate and enjoy my meal comfortably.  I definitely recommend this place!
author: Virginie J.

description: High protein or protein-only diets can be hard to adhere to. Not at Caffe Bianco- they have Prosciutto (bad jew!) and a meatloaf that doesn't exactly rival mom's but tastes pretty damn good and is a deal at around $4 a slice. Plus, there's an added iron kick in there from the spinach). They also have diet Dr. Pepper (me) and Protein shakes (for boy). Pass on the marinara sauce on your meatloaf (it's on the tinny side) and take it cold- it loses it's herby flavor when warm. I can't wait to go back for the pesto pasta once these last 10 lbs come off. It looks divine.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Old world charm, friendly staff and great eats - an inviting oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle!

I love this place and always feel like I am in a scene from Casablanca when I pass through its historic doors and take in the vaulted ceilings, marble floor and lovely ambiance - the dapper and personable owner is usually there and looks like he could be a part of the movie, too.

This place is perfect for casual yet nice business lunches or coffee meetings with colleagues new or old.  The airy environment makes a welcome alternative to stuffy offices or chains.

Definitely recommend this cafe - it's a gem!
author: Glitter K.

description:
Awesome breakfast/lunch spot downtown. I hit both today. Started with the Cafe Bianco, which is a mix of the house coffee and cinnamon, delicious. That was accompanied by egg whites and salsa wrapped in lavash bread. The perfect combo.

A bigger than normal breakfast leads to a smaller than usual lunch, and after spotting half sandwiches on the menu in the morning, I returned for a tasty house baked turkey cranberry sandwich. No complaints whatsoever.
author: Jason B.

description: It's a nice spacious area with good sized tables.  However, I got the roast-beef sandwich and it was disappointing - dry, tasteless, and small.
author: Sushant P.

description: It's a funny place; kind of like they just threw a salad bar in the lobby of an office building. Actually, that's exactly what it's like. But they have sandwiches and soups and fresh fruit, too, and plenty of seating. Overall, not a bad option.
author: Megan W.

description:
In these tough economic times (hi Britt!), Cafe Bianco serves your financial district food and beverage needs at a fraction of the cost of some of its nearby competition.

My coworkers and I would come in for their coffees. I like the white mocha (it's really sweet) and the coworkers like their chai lattes. Generally these are like 2.25 or under 3.00 - a cheaper option than Starbucks or Peet's (and I freakin love Peet's)

For the afternoon, we like the Italian sodas (yes it's soda water and syrup, but it still tastes great).

Then we discovered the breakfast burritos! Well Stephanie K. told me about them. They're a perfect breakfast size and you can get them with egg whites with your choice of added sausage, bacon or whatever. Great when you want more than cereal for breakfast.

I always saw the salad bar but was kind of wary - but now I love this too! Fill up a box with your favorite salad ingredients and it's charged by weight. I want to say it's $5 per pound. So long as you don't load up on like 10 beets, the coworker and I stay under a pound pretty easily.

And their regular lunch options are proving to be pretty great too. My salad sampler today was 6.95 - I got generous helpings of pesto pasta, curry rice with chicken and portabello mushrooms with tofu.

It's just a nice option for when you don't want to spend $10 dollars at Mixt or nearly $10 for some sort of sandwich. (and you're too lazy to bring lunch like I am a lot of days)

Accepts credit cards for purchases over $5 or they charge like a .35 surcharge

Oh and their menus are all over the place, which is probably why I keep discovering things like weeks later. Don't be discouraged by the odd decor!
author: Karen J.

description: This is a great place for a morning pit stop! I had their Chi latte today and it was superb, even better than $tarbuck$ and at a much more reasonable price! They also have a great selection of fresh fruit, bagels, and breakfast burritos. The service is excellent, they get you through quickly and everyone is nice. I have stopped there a couple of times for lunch and their sandwiches are pretty good as well.
author: Kristin D.

description: This is just an average and un-interesting lunch spot in the findist.  I worked in this area for years and it took me a while to get there and when I finally went there I was non-delighted.  I think if you are going to spend money for lunch--it should be delightful, exceptional.  I think the findist is not a cheap place to have lunch.  I do expect a lot because every dollar I get is very hard earned.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Bianco gets outsourced by Sutter Station at lunch time which makes for a pretty good pair. The sandwiches are pretty standard, but also not too expensive, leaving a little change in your pocket for a noontime beer. I'll have to visit Bianco proper to allow for a more robust review, but until then an average 3 stars.
author: Michael E.

description: One of the few places in the city where you can buy a 16 oz. drink for less than $3. Kudos on the pricing and flavor, jeers to the $5 minimum (or a fee will be charged) for credit cards.
author: Selina L.

description: Had a lovely latte here. Maybe one day I will get to try the rest of the menu.
author: Stephanie W.

description: it's right behind my office and offers a delicious chicken wrap.
author: Greg H.

description: Caffe Bianco is a god place to grasp a fast breakfast and lunch.  The owner is a very nice guy and his workers are mostly helpful.  I use to have my oatmeal and boiled egg for breakfast, sometimes a bagel toasted with cream cheese or a low fat blueberry muffin.  Coffee is fine there.  For lunch, I love the salad bar, with lot of choices of green.  Potato salad, bean salad, apple salad, pasta salad are all so tasty.  One of the must try is the lavash wrap.  Try the chicken ceaser or the caper tuna and you won't be disappointed.  My husband tried its meatloaf and lasanga, he likes it.  The price is quite reasonable for a downtown restaurant in Financial District.  Well, I also like the smoothies but it's a bit quite pricey.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Any place that gives you real cups and saucers and has little marble tables gets a plus, even if the tea selection is semi-uninspired.  It's friendly, not too crowded, and a good place to have work meetings over coffee because it's quiet and spacious with nice tables.  Their lunch food doesn't look inspiring, but the pumpkin scone I had there once and the proximity to my office go a long way.  With how crowded some other FiDi spots get, the quiet dim upstairs is a nice change of pace Once my friend sweet-talked the cashier (en espanol, claro) into "lending" her a bag of chips to eat upstairs until she could bum cash off of me to pay for it.
author: Gloria B.

description: Decent coffee, but it is an odd atmosphere and something just feels a little off. However it's really the only coffee spot near me that has a good amount of tables.
author: Chris B.

description: Pleasant north-beach style cafe with marble tables, homey atmosphere, right in the heart of downtown. Quiet and easy place to work from on this Thursday afternoon. I can't figure out why anyone would sit in starbucks when you can hang out here. Wifi access if you ask behind the counter for the password.  Good coffee, and looks to be a kick ass lasagna for $5.50 - wish I hadn't eaten lunch.
author: Jaymz D.

description:
Having worked upstairs from Cafe Bianco for almost two years, it has worked its way into my heart. The coffee is great, and all fair trade. Everyone is friendly, the prices area reasonable, and the food is tasty and fresh.

It's a shame it's not open on weekends or later at night- but it really caters to the financial district lunch crowd. The side with a salad bar and burritos isn't quite as nice as the main counter, but it's convenient, fast, and clean. I like how the whole place is sort of welcoming, with decent music that's not too loud and a steady stream of interesting artwork on the walls.

I can't find another place to get coconut macaroons- Cafe Trieste has them, but theirs are no better, cost more, and are smaller. I hope this place lasts forever. With all of the fast food garbage, and all of the really mediocre independent eateries out there, it's great to know you can stop in at Cafe Bianco for something wholesome that doesn't cost an arm and a leg.

I'd give it 4.5 stars if I could, but not five. It's a dependable favorite of mine, but if you're willing to pay enough you can probably get better food elsewhere. It's an awesome lunch spot, but I reserve five stars for the elusive combination of stellar quality and value.
author: joe c.

description: This place is very a very mom/pop shop - and I adore it.  The people are super friendly, the food is always good (not fanastic, but solid), the prices reasonable, and the lines not too long.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Quaint place. Cheap coffe. But, the ham quiche I was served had a total of four small (1/8 x 1/8") chuncks of ham. The crust was soft and not flaky as expected. The texture was odd, not unpleasant but different than any I have ever tried. I will give it snother shot since it is quick and close to work. But, Bianco won't become my go-to spot.
author: Mary H.

description: I've been working so close to this place for the past 5 years and would have never noticed this place nor eaten here had it not been a suggestion made by Marcia W. Located inside an old office building, it faces out to Sutter Street, but is accessable through this easily missed lobby door that faces out to Market St (right next to GNC and 7-Eleven). There's also a nail salon and alterations shop in the lobby, and you can tell that the owners have been there for a long time. The cafe has a big selection, so if you are feeling up for anything, you'll be able to find something there. There's a big salad bar, where you can make your own salad for $5, a burrito station (I got a small chicken burrito which was quite good and the perfect portion for only $3.50), sandwiches, pastas and soups. Everything is priced around $5, which is great if you're someone like me who eats out practically every day. Very casual and nothing fussy, lots of seating and not too many people.
author: Connie C.

description: I have been going to Caffe Bianco for over 15 years, I bet. I just walked by it yesterday, and thought again to myself, how happy I am that it is there. (Didn't have time to stop in and eat though.) Their sandwiches are custom made, and they're nice about tweaking things with whatver extras that make you happy. Soups, salads, lasagna... plenty of variety for everybody. They aren't spectacularly creative meals -- but just nice pleasant food, at nice pleasant prices, served by nice pleasant people. Good espresso drinks too. The thing I probably like the most about it is the ambiance. It's quirky there among the office buildings. Huge windows to let in a lot of light, and a somewhat European flavor to the decor.  Lots of little round marble tables to sit at -- and the best kept secret is that there are stairs off to the side and a whole upstairs section with even more seating (still with the window light) for when the place looks full. I really like supporting the little guys, and although there are probably 75 Starbuck's within a block of here, if you feel like sitting down and reading the paper and enjoying a good latte -- this is definitely the better option.
author: Zoe H.

description: Nice place to grab a salad or sandwich... pretty quiet atmosphere right in downtown... reasonable prices too... I recommend the Bianco Club on sourdough bread.  The Chicken Caesar is a nice choice too... the staff and owner are friendly...
author: Amar M.

description: This place is okay. Sandwiches are small and they slap wwaayyy too much mayo on the bread. The staff were all really nice.
author: Danielle S.

description: I like their sandwiches. Quite a bit. And the price is OK. But again and again, I am put off by how unfriendly the two people behind the cash register are (the man with the moustache and a lady). The sandwich preparers are fine. I am not usually that sensitive to frowns, but those two just make me want to go money elsewhere. As if it's bother to take my money.
author: Victoria A.

description: before you scoff at me and impugn my credibility for having given some old world cafe in the financial district four stars, please hear me out.  yes... i know cafe bianco isnt going to win any awards for its food, but in the somewhat monochromatic downtown scene filled with the likes of specialitys, chili up, lee's, generic burrito places, starbucks, et al., cafe bianco's old world charm really shines through.  the food is typical cafe style with sandwiches, some hot plate items and your typical salad bar.  the main room has a lofted ceiling, is airy yet cozy, seating is plentiful both on the cafe level as well as on the mezzanine level.  music selection is always jazz or classical.  prices are cheap and the food is satisfying (i like the breakfast burrito with fresh fruit for under $3.00 and the meatloaf on penne pasta with marinara sauce and baguette for $5.70)  okay, so that doesnt exactly blow you away, but if you work near sutter and market, i urge you to step into cafe bianco for a coffee break and check it out.  youll find yourself wanting to just kick back for a while and relax, and thats worth something in these fast paced times, isnt it?
author: Curtis Y.
